   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 2 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.  Appreciate IP
   assistance.
   -
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her. There is concern for possible worsening mental status, as now does
   not appear to withdraw to noxious stimuli. Her CT head has been
   stable.  If there are any changes in her imaging concerning for
   worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 7. Goal
   gent <2 for once daily dosing.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE as noted
no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but
   abnormalities as noted above.
   - Initiated keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] and stopping phenytoin. Combination of
   two overlapping anti-epileptics could be part of reason for decreased
   mental status.
   - Head CT from last two days without change, checking today to ensure
   no further change given question of change in mental status. If
   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Will work on optimizing reversible factors such as hypernatremia,
   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ID recommending repeat LP on Monday.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - FDP 10-40, hapto <20, could be hemolyzing for unclear reasons (no
   literature for Keppra as cause of hemolysis); Heme evaluated smear, no
   evidence for hemolysis
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Hct stable post transfusion
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coags every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team this morning, listeria
   can have similar presentation to viral hepatitis.  Lipase elevated
   today
           -      recheck lipase
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible
   losses. She will need more free water repletion, but now NPG x 48 hrs,
   concern for giving D5W given CNS issues.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Start D5W gently to decrease Na as pt is now NPO/NPG until at least
   Monday
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: Unclear if this represents true
   infection, but suspect at present this is likely not true pneumonia as
   she does not have a significant/new amount of sputum, no leukocytosis,
   and overall fever curve has improved. Chest x-ray also remains
   unimpressive for infection. Will have low threshold to initiate
   treatment, respiratory therapy completed a mini-BAL yesterday that
   showed no microorganisms or PMNs.
   - Bronchial washings performed by IP: culture pending, no micro seen
   # Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Sent beta glucan pre and post Amp dosing to ascertain whether
   elevated level is related to abx
   #) Hypotension: Patient with transient hypotension overnight. This,
   coupled with her hypernatremia, borderline tachycardia, dry mucous
   membranes, all support volume depleted state. Monitoring closely for
   worsening sepsis. Will continue LR boluses to keep up urine output
   >40-50 cc/hour, SBP >90, and HR<100.
   # Peg: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of
   leak in stomach/peritonitis.
   - Gastrograffin study Monday
   - IP following

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a complex medical history, including autoimmune disease, who presented with seizure, Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection and is receiving antibiotics, including ampicillin and gentamicin, for the Listeria infection.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has elevated respiratory rate, likely secondary to the CNS process.
* Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: The patient's mental status has deteriorated, and she is not responding to noxious stimuli. Her CT head has been stable, but there is concern for possible worsening mental status.
* Pancytopenia: The patient has elevated MCV with pancytopenia, which is consistent with Imuran toxicity.
* Elevated INR: The patient's INR is elevated, suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
* Elevated LFTs: The patient's LFTs are elevated, with RUQ consistent with liver disease.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible losses.
* Question of increased pigmentation: The patient has a history of darkening skin pigment over the last months to years, which may be related to her autoimmune disease or other underlying conditions.
* Gram negative rods in sputum: The patient has Gram negative rods in her sputum, which may represent true infection or colonization.
* Positive beta-glucan: The patient's beta-glucan level is positive, which may indicate fungal infection, particularly given her recent immunosuppression.
* Hypotension: The patient has transient hypotension, which may be related to volume depletion or sepsis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Worsening mental status: The patient's mental status has deteriorated, and there is concern for possible worsening mental status.
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and her current condition may be related to ongoing infection.
* Pneumonia: The patient has Gram negative rods in her sputum, which may represent true infection or colonization.
* Fungal infection: The patient's positive beta-glucan level may indicate fungal infection, particularly given her recent immunosuppression.
* Liver disease: The patient's LFTs are elevated, with RUQ consistent with liver disease.
* Hemolytic anemia: The patient's pancytopenia and elevated MCV may be related to hemolytic anemia.
* Vitamin deficiency: The patient's elevated INR may be related to nutritional deficiencies.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics, including ampicillin and gentamicin, for the Listeria infection.
* IV fluids: The patient is receiving IV fluids, including D5W, to manage her hypernatremia.
* Nutrition: The patient is receiving nutrition support, including glycemic control.
* Monitoring: The patient is being closely monitored for signs of worsening sepsis, pneumonia, and other complications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

The patient's facial twitching, which broke with 2 mg of ativan, has been treated with a dilantin load of 500 mg, followed by 500 mg in the morning and 100 mg TID. The patient's transient hypotension after 3 mg of ativan responded to a 500cc LR bolus. Gentamicin dosing has been changed to Q12H due to high levels.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, and blood pressure ranging from 105/47 mmHg to 129/63 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 40%, and SpO2 is 100%. The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.9 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 6.9 K/uL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an ALT of 27 and AST of 29.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Seizure control: The patient's facial twitching and response to ativan may indicate a seizure disorder, which requires close monitoring and management.
2. Hypotension: The patient's transient hypotension after ativan administration may indicate a risk of hypotension, which requires close monitoring and prompt treatment.
3. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes may indicate an infection, which requires further investigation and treatment.
4. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's fluctuating blood pressure and heart rate may indicate hemodynamic instability, which requires close monitoring and management.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support and elevated respiratory rate may indicate a risk of respiratory failure, which requires close monitoring and management.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's altered coagulation profile and elevated liver enzymes may indicate a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which requires close monitoring and management.
7. Renal failure: The patient's altered electrolyte profile and elevated creatinine level may indicate a risk of renal failure, which requires close monitoring and management.
8. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's altered electrolyte profile and elevated troponin level may indicate a risk of cardiovascular instability, which requires close monitoring and management.

Overall, the patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and optimize their outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with seizure overnight.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 4 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.  RSBI 72
   today.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**7-25**].
   -          Will diurese as tolerated by blood pressure, but need to
   watch K and replete aggressively, given seizure at time of hypokalemia;
   pt required 2 fluid boluses yesterday for low BP.
   -          SBT again today
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] (now IV given cannot use PEG), added Dilantin
   given seizure activity, will discuss need for both agents.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ID recommending repeat LP on today, will need to ensure that fungal,
   AFB, and modified cultures sent (eg to evaluate for Nocardia).
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will try to
   determine how lab samples may be distinguished, given they appear in
   OMR as having been collected at the same time.
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient with right facial twitching overnight felt to be
   seizure activity. This would be consistent in distribution given that
   her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It is possible
   that her hypokalemic state contributed to her seizure. Given lower HCT,
   concern was for bleed, however CT not supportive of this or of
   worsening edema/mass effect or other new pathology. Other consideration
   would be that seizures are less well controlled on keppra, given that
   phenytoin has been stopped and is likely now no longer therapeutic.
   Will discuss further with neurology if patient again has seizure
   without other possible explanation. Checking electrolytes TID while
   diuresing, etc
   - F/U Neuro recs re: anticonvulsants
 Keppra 1500 [**Hospital1 **], Dilantin 100
   TID today, [**Hospital1 **] tomorrow, QD on Wednesday, then stop Dilantin
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **]-TID HCTs.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, suspected to be secondary to nutritional
   deficiencies. Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well
   as FFPs at presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC
   appears to be less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this
   possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CTs as well as coags every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently. T. bili trending downward.
           -      Will continue to trend lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Improved with D5W, will continue to monitor, but
   given she cannot use her PEG yet, will likely need additional D5W (no
   worsening edema after D5W given).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Start D5W gently to decrease Na as pt is now NPO/NPG until at least
   Monday
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. No PMNs upon
   bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to interpret.
   Additionally, fever curve improving. Will have low threshold to
   initiate treatment should fever curve, secretions, or WBC worsen.
   #) Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Will attempt to determine which sample was pre and which was post
   ampicillin administration.
   #) PEG: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of
   leak in stomach/peritonitis. CT negative for acute change upon
   preliminary review this morning.
   - Gastrograffin study Monday
   - IP following
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Holding TF until PEG evaluated.
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin SS as needed

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with seizure overnight.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 4 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.  RSBI 72
   today.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**7-25**].
   -          Will diurese as tolerated by blood pressure, but need to
   watch K and replete aggressively, given seizure at time of hypokalemia;
   pt required 2 fluid boluses yesterday for low BP.
   -          SBT again today
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] (now IV given cannot use PEG), added Dilantin
   given seizure activity, will discuss need for both agents.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ID recommending repeat LP on today, will need to ensure that fungal,
   AFB, and modified cultures sent (eg to evaluate for Nocardia).
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will try to
   determine how lab samples may be distinguished, given they appear in
   OMR as having been collected at the same time.
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient with right facial twitching overnight felt to be
   seizure activity. This would be consistent in distribution given that
   her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It is possible
   that her hypokalemic state contributed to her seizure. Given lower HCT,
   concern was for bleed, however CT not supportive of this or of
   worsening edema/mass effect or other new pathology. Other consideration
   would be that seizures are less well controlled on keppra, given that
   phenytoin has been stopped and is likely now no longer therapeutic.
   Will discuss further with neurology if patient again has seizure
   without other possible explanation. Checking electrolytes TID while
   diuresing, etc
   - F/U Neuro recs re: anticonvulsants
 Keppra 1500 [**Hospital1 **], Dilantin 100
   TID today, [**Hospital1 **] tomorrow, QD on Wednesday, then stop Dilantin
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **]-TID HCTs.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, suspected to be secondary to nutritional
   deficiencies. Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well
   as FFPs at presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC
   appears to be less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this
   possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CTs as well as coags every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently. T. bili trending downward.
           -      Will continue to trend lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).

   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Improved with D5W, will continue to monitor, but
   given she cannot use her PEG yet, will likely need additional D5W (no
   worsening edema after D5W given).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Start D5W gently to decrease Na as pt is now NPO/NPG until at least
   Monday
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or

   significant secretions to suggest true infection. No PMNs upon

   Additionally, fever curve improving. Will have low threshold to

   #) PEG: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease, who was admitted with Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a suspected brain abscess. She has been treated with antibiotics and has shown some improvement in her fever curve. However, she continues to experience seizure activity, pancytopenia, elevated INR, and hypernatremia. She has also developed facial twitching, which was treated with Ativan. The patient's respiratory status remains stable, but she requires ongoing respiratory support.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure activity: The patient's seizure activity is a concern, and it is important to monitor her electrolyte levels and adjust her anticonvulsant therapy as needed.
2. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia is likely related to Imuran toxicity, and it is important to monitor her hemoglobin and platelet counts closely.
3. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR is likely related to nutritional deficiencies, and it is important to monitor her coagulation studies closely.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is a concern, and it is important to monitor her sodium levels closely to prevent further electrolyte imbalances.
5. Infection: The patient's positive beta-glucan result suggests a possible fungal infection, and it is important to monitor her for signs of infection and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains stable, but she requires ongoing respiratory support, and it is important to monitor her for signs of respiratory failure.
7. Neurological compromise: The patient's neurological status is a concern, and it is important to monitor her for signs of neurological compromise, such as decreased mental status or increased intracranial pressure.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust her anticonvulsant therapy as needed.
2. Monitor the patient's pancytopenia and adjust her Imuran therapy as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's elevated INR and adjust her coagulation therapy as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's hypernatremia and adjust her fluid therapy as needed.
5. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her respiratory support as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust her therapy as needed.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to follow the patient's culture data and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
2. Consider repeating the patient's beta-glucan test to confirm the presence of a fungal infection.
3. Consider repeating the patient's head CT to monitor for signs of neurological compromise.
4. Consider repeating the patient's blood cultures to monitor for signs of infection.
5. Consider adjusting the patient's anticonvulsant therapy to better control her seizure activity.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with seizure overnight.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 4 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**7-25**].
   -          Will diurese as tolerated by blood pressure, but need to
   watch K and replete aggressively, given seizure at time of hypokalemia;
   pt required 2 fluid boluses yesterday for low BP.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] (now IV given cannot use PEG), added Dilantin
   given seizure activity, will discuss need for both agents.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ID recommending repeat LP on [**Last Name (LF) 305**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] need to ensure that fungal,
   AFB, and modified cultures sent (eg to evaluate for Nocardia).
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will try to
   determine how lab samples may be distinguished, given they appear in
   OMR as having been collected at the same time.
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient with right facial twitching overnight felt to be
   seizure activity. This would be consistent in distribution given that
   her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It is possible
   that her hypokalemic state contributed to her seizure. Given lower HCT,
   concern was for bleed, however CT not supportive of this or of
   worsening edema/mass effect or other new pathology. Other consideration
   would be that seizures are less well controlled on keppra, given that
   phenytoin has been stopped and is likely now no longer therapeutic.
   Will discuss further with neurology if patient again has seizure
   without other possible explanation. Checking electrolytes TID while
   diuresing, etc.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **]-TID HCTs.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, suspected to be secondary to nutritional
   deficiencies. Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well
   as FFPs at presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC
   appears to be less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this
   possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CTs as well as coags every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no

   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease, who presented with a seizure, Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for airway protection and is being treated with antibiotics. The patient has experienced several complications, including:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and is being managed with pressure support.
* Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: The patient has been treated with antibiotics and has had serial head CT scans, which have been stable.
* Pancytopenia: The patient has been diagnosed with pancytopenia, which is thought to be secondary to Imuran toxicity.
* Elevated INR: The patient has an elevated INR, which is thought to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
* Elevated LFTs: The patient has elevated liver function tests, which are thought to be secondary to liver disease.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which is being treated with D5W.
* Question of increased pigmentation: The patient has a history of darkening skin pigment, which is being evaluated by dermatology.
* Gram negative rods in sputum: The patient has gram negative rods in her sputum, which are thought to be a contaminant.
* Positive beta-glucan: The patient has a positive beta-glucan test, which is thought to be an indicator of fungal infection.
* PEG: The patient has a PEG tube, which is being monitored for evidence of leak or peritonitis.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to her underlying condition and the need for intubation.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her immunosuppressed state and the presence of gram negative rods in her sputum.
* Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to her pancytopenia and elevated INR.
* Liver failure: The patient is at risk for liver failure due to her elevated LFTs and liver disease.
* Hypernatremia: The patient is at risk for hypernatremia due to her underlying condition and the need for D5W.
* Increased pigmentation: The patient is at risk for increased pigmentation due to her underlying condition and the presence of gram negative rods in her sputum.
* Fungal infection: The patient is at risk for fungal infection due to her positive beta-glucan test and immunosuppressed state.
* Peritonitis: The patient is at risk for peritonitis due to her PEG tube and the presence of gram negative rods in her sputum.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her management accordingly.
* Continue to treat the patient's Listeria infection with antibiotics and monitor her response.
* Monitor the patient's pancytopenia and adjust her management accordingly.
* Monitor the patient's INR and adjust her management accordingly.
* Monitor the patient's LFTs and adjust her management accordingly.
* Monitor the patient's hypernatremia and adjust her management accordingly.
* Monitor the patient's pigmentation and adjust her management accordingly.
* Consider empiric treatment for fungal infection based on the patient's positive beta-glucan test.
* Monitor the patient's PEG tube for evidence of leak or peritonitis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old individual admitted to the ICU with a complex medical condition. The patient's chief complaint is not specified, but the note highlights several significant events and changes in their condition.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 73 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 100/51 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, and their oxygen saturation is 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.0 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 86 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 5.2 mEq/L.

The patient's imaging studies, including a chest x-ray, are pending. The patient's culture data shows the presence of pan-sensitive acinetobacter and yeast in their bronchial washings, blood, and mini-BAL cultures.

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and antihypertensives. The patient's Keppra and Dilantin doses are being weaned, and they are receiving 1 mg of lorazepam as needed for seizure control.

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing ICU care, nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's culture data shows the presence of pan-sensitive acinetobacter and yeast, which can lead to sepsis if not properly treated.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and they require mechanical ventilation. Prolonged mechanical ventilation can lead to respiratory failure.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's anticonvulsant therapy is being weaned, and they are at risk for seizure recurrence.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis may not be adequate, and they are at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated, and they may be at risk for cardiovascular complications such as hypertension or cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Infection control: The patient's presence of yeast in their cultures may indicate an infection that requires proper control and management.
7. Metabolic complications: The patient's electrolyte levels may require close monitoring and management to prevent metabolic complications such as hyperkalemia.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their therapy accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with seizure overnight.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 4 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.  RSBI 77
   today.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**4-24**].
   -          SBT again today
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12. (day 10)
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] (now IV given cannot use PEG), added Dilantin
   given seizure activity, will discuss need for both agents.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ID recommending repeat LP on today, will need to ensure that fungal,
   AFB, and modified cultures sent (eg to evaluate for Nocardia).
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will try to
   determine how lab samples may be distinguished, given they appear in
   OMR as having been collected at the same time.
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient with right facial twitching overnight felt to be
   seizure activity. This would be consistent in distribution given that
   her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It is possible
   that her hypokalemic state contributed to her seizure. Given lower HCT,
   concern was for bleed, however CT not supportive of this or of
   worsening edema/mass effect or other new pathology. Other consideration
   would be that seizures are less well controlled on keppra, given that
   phenytoin has been stopped and is likely now no longer therapeutic.
   Will discuss further with neurology if patient again has seizure
   without other possible explanation. Checking electrolytes TID while
   diuresing, etc
   - F/U Neuro recs re: anticonvulsants
 Keppra 1500 [**Hospital1 **], Dilantin 100
   TID today, [**Hospital1 **] tomorrow, QD on Wednesday, then stop Dilantin
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **]-TID HCTs.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, suspected to be secondary to nutritional
   deficiencies. Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well
   as FFPs at presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC
   appears to be less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this
   possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CTs as well as coags every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently. T. bili trending downward.
           -      Will continue to trend lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Improved with D5W, will continue to monitor, but
   given she cannot use her PEG yet, will likely need additional D5W (no
   worsening edema after D5W given).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Start D5W gently to decrease Na as pt is now NPO/NPG until at least
   Monday
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. No PMNs upon
   bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to interpret.
   Additionally, fever curve improving. Will have low threshold to
   initiate treatment should fever curve, secretions, or WBC worsen.
   #) Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Will attempt to determine which sample was pre and which was post
   ampicillin administration.
   #) PEG: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of
   leak in stomach/peritonitis. CT negative for acute change upon
   preliminary review this morning.
   - Gastrograffin study Monday
   - IP following
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease, who presented with a seizure, Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for airway protection and has been treated with antibiotics. Her condition has been stable, with some fluctuations in her vital signs and laboratory values.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, likely due to her CNS process. Close monitoring and adjustment of her respiratory support is necessary.
2. Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: The patient's infection is likely to continue to progress, and close monitoring of her imaging and laboratory values is necessary to determine the best course of treatment.
3. Seizure: The patient's seizure activity may be related to her Listeria infection, and close monitoring of her electrolytes and anticonvulsant levels is necessary.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia is likely related to her Imuran treatment, and close monitoring of her complete blood counts is necessary.
5. Elevated INR: The patient's INR is stable, but close monitoring of her coagulation studies is necessary to determine the best course of treatment.
6. Elevated LFTs: The patient's LFTs are stable, but close monitoring of her liver function is necessary to determine the best course of treatment.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is likely related to her inability to use her PEG, and close monitoring of her sodium levels is necessary.
8. Question of increased pigmentation: The patient's family history of darkening skin pigment and her own reports of skin darkening may be related to an underlying condition, and close monitoring of her skin pigmentation is necessary.
9. Acinetobacter in sputum: The patient's Acinetobacter in her sputum may be related to her underlying infection, and close monitoring of her respiratory status is necessary.
10. Positive beta-glucan: The patient's positive beta-glucan result may indicate a fungal infection, particularly given her recent immunosuppression. Close monitoring of her fungal cultures and treatment is necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely.
2. Adjust the patient's anticonvulsant medications as necessary to control her seizure activity.
3. Continue to treat the patient's Listeria infection with antibiotics.
4. Monitor the patient's pancytopenia and adjust her Imuran treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's INR and adjust her anticoagulation treatment as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's LFTs and adjust her treatment as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's hypernatremia and adjust her fluid management as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's skin pigmentation and adjust her treatment as necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's Acinetobacter in her sputum and adjust her respiratory treatment as necessary.
10. Monitor the patient's beta-glucan result and adjust her treatment as necessary.

ICU Care:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely.
2. Adjust the patient's anticonvulsant medications as necessary to control her seizure activity.
3. Continue to treat the patient's Listeria infection with antibiotics.
4. Monitor the patient's pancytopenia and adjust her Imuran treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's INR and adjust her anticoagulation treatment as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's LFTs and adjust her treatment as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's hypernatremia and adjust her fluid management as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's skin pigmentation and adjust her treatment as necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's Acinetobacter in her sputum and adjust her respiratory treatment as necessary.
10. Monitor the patient's beta-glucan result and adjust her treatment as necessary.

Nutrition:

1. Continue to provide the patient with nutrition as necessary to support her recovery.
2. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust her nutrition as necessary.

Glycemic Control:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust her treatment as necessary to maintain glycemic control.

Lines:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's arterial line and multi-lumen lines for any signs of complications.

Prophylaxis:

1. Continue to provide the patient with prophylactic antibiotics as necessary to prevent infection.

Code Status:

1. The patient's code status is full code.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with continued activity concerning for seizures.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, and underwent tracheostomy on
   [**2124-9-22**]. Her elevated respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS
   process.  RSBI 77 today.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**4-24**], so will transition to breathing trial and re-check ABG
   afterwards, with transition to trach mask if possible.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status, however there is concern for
   intermittent seizure activity (twitching of right cheek,
   opening/closing of mouth, moving of head).
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12. (Today is day 10)
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data, and plan to repeat LP today
   after CT head, to send for fungal, AFB, modified cultures (to exclude
   Nocardia).
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role (once can give PO
s again)
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will look
   for change in level (since both samples timed alike).
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient has had intermittent movements that could be
   consistent with seizures, such as right facial twitching, mouth
   movement, and head shaking. This would be consistent in distribution
   given that her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It
   is difficult to say if these activities have been seizures, and they
   have stopped after administration of ativan.
   - Requested 24 EEG monitoring to assess if activities correlate with
   EEG evidence of seizures (EEG had not suggestive of non-convulsive
   status)
   - Increased Keppra to 1500 mg [**Hospital1 **], Dilantin 100 [**Hospital1 **] today, then 100
   daily, then stop
   - Repeat head CT today.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Stable. Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with
   pancytopenia is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other
   possibilities being B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less
   likely malignancy. B12 and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor [**Hospital1 1174**], transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated Coagulation Studies: PTT increased today, suspect likely
   secondary to systemic absorption of subcutaneous heparin. Her elevated
   INR had been felt to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies and liver
   disease. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be less
   likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Following [**Last Name (LF) 1174**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] need to ensure PTT is lower (eg <40) prior to
   LP today.
   - Holding SQ heparin today.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently. T. bili trending downward.

s, or

   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, doing well on trach mask, with possible continued
   intermittent seizures.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, and underwent tracheostomy on
   [**2124-9-22**]. She has done well on trach mask for over 24 hours now, with
   a re-assuring ABG. Will continue on trach mask with Fi02 of 50%, wean
   FiO2 if possible, follow up ABG in AM, or if patient has other acute
   change.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable. TTE and TEE completed as
   noted (abnormal, but no definite abscess or vegetation). Currently, her
   fevers have resolved, however no change in mental status. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status, however there is concern for
   intermittent seizure activity (twitching of right cheek,
   opening/closing of mouth, moving of head).
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12. (Today is day 11)
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data, and plan to repeat LP today to
   send for fungal, AFB, modified cultures (to exclude Nocardia), given
   PTT is normal this morning after holding subcutaneous heparin.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role (once can give PO
s again)
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will look
   for change in level (since both samples timed alike).
   - MR with contrast and MR spectroscopy to be completed to evaluate for
   other etiologies of frontal mass, as per discussion with neurology team
   after interdisciplinary conference, there is concern that her mass is
   not completely consistent with a listeria abscess. MR spectroscopy
   could help evaluate for lymphoma.
   .
   #) Seizure: No abnormal movements noted over last 24 hours. Prior to
   that time, patient has had intermittent movements that could be
   consistent with seizures, such as right facial twitching, mouth
   movement, and head shaking. This would be consistent in distribution
   given that her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It
   is difficult to say if these activities have been seizures, and they
   have stopped after administration of ativan.
   - Requested 24 EEG monitoring to assess if activities correlate with
   EEG evidence of seizures (EEG had not suggestive of non-convulsive
   status), which is being set up today. Routine EEG completed yesterday,
   will follow up results.
   - Increased Keppra to 1500 mg [**Hospital1 **], Dilantin 100 once today, then stop
   - Will follow up final head CT and MR to be done today.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Stable. Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with
   pancytopenia is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other
   possibilities being B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less
   likely malignancy. B12 and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated Coagulation Studies: PTT down after holding subcutaneous
   heparin, suspect this was secondary to systemic absorption of
   subcutaneous heparin. Her elevated INR had been felt to be secondary to
   nutritional deficiencies and liver disease. Per hematology and
   laboratory values, DIC appears to be less likely, but still will
   continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Holding SQ heparin today until after LP, then will re-start at [**Hospital1 **]
   dosing.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently.
           -      Will continue to trend lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Re-starting free water flushes, will re-check PM
   sodium.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or

   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. Fevers have resolved.
   No PMNs upon bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to

   - Contact precautions, will follow up repeat sputum culture (NGTD)

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease, who presented with seizure, Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. She has been intubated for airway protection and underwent tracheostomy. The patient has been on trach mask ventilation for over 24 hours with reassuring ABG. She has been treated with ampicillin and gentamicin for Listeria infection. The patient's mental status remains unchanged, with no response to verbal, tactile, or noxious stimuli. She has been experiencing intermittent seizures, and EEG monitoring is being set up to assess for seizure activity.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and weaning from trach mask ventilation may be challenging.
2. Listeria infection: The patient's infection is ongoing, and the risk of sepsis and organ failure remains high.
3. Seizure activity: The patient's seizure activity may be a sign of ongoing brain injury or infection, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent further seizures.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia may be related to Imuran toxicity, and close monitoring of blood counts is necessary to prevent bleeding or infection.
5. Elevated coagulation studies: The patient's elevated INR and PTT may be related to nutritional deficiencies, liver disease, or systemic absorption of subcutaneous heparin.
6. Elevated LFTs: The patient's elevated LFTs may be related to liver disease or medication toxicity, and close monitoring is necessary to prevent liver failure.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be related to inadequate free water flushes, and re-checking of sodium levels is necessary.
8. Question of increased pigmentation: The patient's history of darkening skin pigment may be related to Addison's disease, hemachromatosis, or other underlying medical condition.
9. Acinetobacter in sputum: The patient's sputum culture may indicate colonization rather than true infection, but close monitoring is necessary to prevent respiratory complications.
10. Positive beta-glucan: The patient's positive beta-glucan result may indicate fungal infection, particularly given recent immunosuppression.

Recommendations:

1. Continue trach mask ventilation and monitor respiratory status closely.
2. Continue treatment with ampicillin and gentamicin for Listeria infection.
3. Monitor seizure activity closely and consider EEG monitoring.
4. Monitor pancytopenia closely and transfuse if necessary.
5. Monitor coagulation studies closely and adjust heparin dosing as necessary.
6. Monitor LFTs closely and adjust medication dosing as necessary.
7. Monitor sodium levels closely and re-check hypernatremia.
8. Investigate increased pigmentation further and consider dermatology consultation.
9. Monitor sputum culture results and adjust respiratory therapy as necessary.
10. Consider fungal treatment if beta-glucan result is confirmed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-inch, 57.3 kg individual who was admitted to the ICU with a 24-hour history of invasive ventilation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 114/63 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 100% on a trach mask.

The patient's laboratory results show a WBC count of 3.7 K/uL, Hct of 22.0%, and Plt of 67 K/uL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 5.6 mEq/L. The patient's liver enzymes, including ALT and AST, are elevated, with values of 30 and 35, respectively. The patient's renal function is also impaired, with a creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies, including a head CT and abdomen CT, are negative for any acute changes. The patient's sputum culture is positive for GNR, and the patient's blood cultures are pending.

The patient's medical history is significant for a recent episode of sepsis, which was treated with antibiotics. The patient is currently receiving IV antibiotics, including daptomycin and gentamicin, as well as antifungal medication.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient is still requiring invasive ventilation. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on a trach mask, but the patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 265, which may indicate some degree of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sputum culture is positive for GNR, and the patient's blood cultures are pending. The patient's WBC count is elevated, and the patient's liver enzymes are elevated, which may indicate a systemic inflammatory response.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and the patient's urine output is decreased. The patient's potassium level is also elevated, which may indicate some degree of renal failure.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, which may indicate some degree of liver dysfunction.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is stable, but the patient's heart rate is slightly elevated. The patient's cardiac enzymes are normal, but the patient's electrocardiogram is not provided.

Based on the patient's laboratory results and imaging studies, the patient's potential medical complications include respiratory failure, sepsis, renal failure, liver dysfunction, and cardiovascular instability.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with continued activity concerning for seizures.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, and underwent tracheostomy on
   [**2124-9-22**]. Her elevated respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS
   process.  RSBI 77 today.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**4-24**], so will transition to breathing trial and re-check ABG
   afterwards, with transition to trach mask if possible.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status, however there is concern for
   intermittent seizure activity (twitching of right cheek,
   opening/closing of mouth, moving of head).
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12. (Today is day 10)
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data, and plan to repeat LP today
   after CT head, to send for fungal, AFB, modified cultures (to exclude
   Nocardia).
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role (once can give PO
s again)
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will look
   for change in level (since both samples timed alike).
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient has had intermittent movements that could be
   consistent with seizures, such as right facial twitching, mouth
   movement, and head shaking. This would be consistent in distribution
   given that her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It
   is difficult to say if these activities have been seizures, and they
   have stopped after administration of ativan.
   - Requested 24 EEG monitoring to assess if activities correlate with
   EEG evidence of seizures (EEG had not suggestive of non-convulsive
   status)
   - Increased Keppra to 1500 mg [**Hospital1 **], Dilantin 100 [**Hospital1 **] today, then 100
   daily, then stop
   - Repeat head CT today.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Stable. Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with
   pancytopenia is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other
   possibilities being B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less
   likely malignancy. B12 and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor [**Hospital1 1174**], transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated Coagulation Studies: PTT increased today, suspect likely
   secondary to systemic absorption of subcutaneous heparin. Her elevated
   INR had been felt to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies and liver
   disease. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be less
   likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Following [**Last Name (LF) 1174**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] need to ensure PTT is lower (eg <40) prior to
   LP today.
   - Holding SQ heparin today.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently. T. bili trending downward.
           -      Will continue to [**First Name3 (LF) 1174**] lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Maintanence fluids with D5W, since cannot use PEG
   yet. Will switch to FW flushes once PEG is usable.
   - Will continue to [**Location (un) 1174**] sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. Fevers have resolved.
   No PMNs upon bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to
   interpret, but suspect colonization.
   - Contact precautions.
   .
   #) Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Will attempt to determine which sample was pre and which was post
   ampicillin administration.
   #) PEG: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of
   leak in stomach/peritonitis. CT negative for acute change upon
   preliminary review this morning.
   - Gastrograffin study today, will follow up results
   - IP following

   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, doing well on trach mask, but remaining obtunded.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, and underwent tracheostomy on
   [**2124-9-22**]. She has done well on trach mask for over 48 hours now, with
   a re-assuring ABG. No significant secretions to suggest pneumonia.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable. TTE and TEE completed as
   noted (abnormal, but no definite abscess or vegetation. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status, however there is concern for
   intermittent seizure activity (twitching of right cheek,
   opening/closing of mouth, moving of head).
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to 120 mg Q 12. (Today is day 12)
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - LP this morning to send for fungal, AFB, modified cultures (to
   exclude Nocardia), given PTT is normal this morning after holding
   subcutaneous heparin.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role (once can give PO
s again)
   - Will discuss B-glucan results with ID team, await results of LP,
   discuss empiric treatment and further sampling of mass.
   - MR with contrast and MR spectroscopy to be completed to evaluate for
   other etiologies of frontal mass, as per discussion with neurology team
   after interdisciplinary conference, there is concern that her mass is
   not completely consistent with a listeria abscess. MR spectroscopy
   could help evaluate for lymphoma.
   .
   #) Seizure: No abnormal movements noted over last 48 hours (last 24 on
   EEG). Prior to that time, patient has had intermittent movements that
   could be consistent with seizures, such as right facial twitching,
   mouth movement, and head shaking. This would be consistent in
   distribution given that her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left
   frontal area. It is difficult to say if these activities have been
   seizures, and they  have stopped after administration of ativan.
   - Will follow up results of 24 hr EEG.
   - Increased Keppra to 1500 mg [**Hospital1 **].
   - MR to be completed today.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Stable. Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with
   pancytopenia is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other
   possibilities being B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less
   likely malignancy. B12 and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated Coagulation Studies: Stable, PTT down after holding
   subcutaneous heparin, suspect this was secondary to systemic absorption
   of subcutaneous heparin. Her elevated INR had been felt to be secondary
   to nutritional deficiencies and liver disease. Per hematology and
   laboratory values, DIC appears to be less likely, but still will
   continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Holding SQ heparin today until after LP, then will re-start at [**Hospital1 **]
   dosing.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable, with some day-to-day variation. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have
   been trending downward, AST/ALT WNL currently.
           -      Will continue to trend lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Resolved. Continue free water flushes at current
   rate.
   .
   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. Fevers have resolved.
   No PMNs upon bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to
   interpret, but suspect colonization.
   - Contact precautions, will follow up repeat sputum culture (which has
   acinetibacter)
   .
   #) Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
